title: 1 Kings Chapter 5 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 1 Kings chapter 5 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 1 Kings Chapter 5 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 1 Kings Chapter 5.

questions.question: Who sent servants to Solomon because he had heard Solomon was anointed king?
questions.correctAnswer: Hiram king of Tyre
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 5:1 states that Hiram king of Tyre sent his servants to Solomon upon hearing he was anointed king.

questions.question: According to 1 Kings 5:3, why could David not build a house for the LORD his God?
questions.correctAnswer: Because of wars around him
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 5:3 explains David could not build the house due to wars on every side.

questions.question: What did Solomon say the LORD had given him that made building the house possible?
questions.correctAnswer: Rest on every side
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 5:4 says the LORD gave Solomon rest on every side, so there was no adversary or evil occurrent.

questions.question: Who did Solomon say would build the house for the LORD according to the LORD's promise?
questions.correctAnswer: Solomon
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 5:5 shows Solomon stating that he, the son of David, would build the house.

questions.question: What type of trees did Solomon request Hiram to command his servants to hew from Lebanon?
questions.correctAnswer: Cedar trees
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 5:6 mentions Solomon asking for cedar trees to be hewed from Lebanon.

questions.question: Why did Solomon say there was no one among them who could skill to hew timber like the Sidonians?
options: Because the trees were too large
questions.correctAnswer: Because Sidonians were skilled workers
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 5:6 states Solomon acknowledged the Sidonians' skill in hewing timber.

questions.question: How did Hiram react when he heard Solomon's words?
questions.correctAnswer: He rejoiced greatly
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 5:7 says Hiram rejoiced greatly upon hearing Solomon's message.

questions.question: What did Hiram promise Solomon concerning the timber of cedar and fir?
options: He would do all Solomon's desire
He would charge a high price
He would send only fir trees
He would send timber from Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: He would do all Solomon's desire
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 5:8 shows Hiram agreeing to fulfill all Solomon's requests regarding timber.

questions.question: How did Hiram plan to deliver the timber to Solomon?
questions.correctAnswer: By sea in floats
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 5:9 describes Hiram's plan to transport timber by sea in floats to Solomon's appointed place.

questions.question: What did Solomon give Hiram in return for the timber yearly?
options: Twenty thousand measures of wheat and twenty measures of pure oil
questions.correctAnswer: Twenty thousand measures of wheat and twenty measures of pure oil
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 5:11 records Solomon giving Hiram wheat and pure oil yearly as payment.

questions.question: True or False: The LORD gave Solomon wisdom as He promised, and there was peace between Hiram and Solomon.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 5:12 confirms the LORD gave Solomon wisdom and there was peace and a league between Hiram and Solomon.

questions.question: True or False: Solomon raised a levy of fifty thousand men from all Israel for the building work.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 5:13 states Solomon raised a levy of thirty thousand men, not fifty thousand.

questions.question: True or False: Adoniram was in charge of the levy sent to Lebanon.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 5:14 shows that Adoniram was over the levy sent to Lebanon.

questions.question: Complete the verse from 1 Kings 5:15: 'And Solomon had __________ that bare burdens, and fourscore thousand hewers in the mountains;'
questions.correctAnswer: threescore and ten thousand
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 5:15 states Solomon had threescore and ten thousand that bare burdens.

questions.question: Who worked together to hew stones and prepare timber and stones to build the house?
questions.correctAnswer: Solomon's builders and Hiram's builders
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 5:18 describes how Solomon's and Hiram's builders both hewed stones and prepared timber.

medium.title: 1 Kings Chapter 5 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 1 Kings Chapter 5 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on 1 Kings 5, what biblical truth would you share about God's provision during times of rest and peace?
options: God grants rest and peace to accomplish His purposes
Trials will never end for a believer
God requires us to act alone without help
Rest means no work is needed
questions.correctAnswer: God grants rest and peace to accomplish His purposes
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 5:3-4 shows that David could not build the house because of wars, but Solomon had rest on every side which allowed him to build. This teaches that God provides seasons of peace to fulfill His plans.

questions.question: How does Solomon demonstrate humility and gratitude in his interaction with Hiram, king of Tyre?
options: He acknowledges Hiram's skill and offers fair payment
He demands free labor and materials
He ignores Hiram’s past kindness to David
He tries to build alone without alliances
questions.correctAnswer: He acknowledges Hiram's skill and offers fair payment
questions.explanation: In 1 Kings 5:6, Solomon recognizes the Sidonians' skill in hewing timber and promises to pay Hiram’s servants fairly, demonstrating humility and gratitude.

questions.question: What can we learn about work ethic from Solomon’s organization of labor for building the house?
options: Diligent planning and division of labor lead to successful work
Work should be done only by the king himself
Only a few people should be responsible for all tasks
Laborers should work without any appointed leaders
questions.correctAnswer: Diligent planning and division of labor lead to successful work
questions.explanation: Verses 13-16 describe Solomon raising 30,000 men with scheduled rotations and officers overseeing thousands more, showing effective work organization and leadership.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with trusting others for help in ministry. Based on 1 Kings 5, what biblical principle about fellowship and cooperation would you share?
options: God calls us to work together with others who have different gifts
Ministry must always be done individually
Only those from the same background can help
Trusting others is a sign of weakness
questions.correctAnswer: God calls us to work together with others who have different gifts
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 5:6-7 shows Solomon and Hiram collaborating, combining their resources and skills, illustrating the importance of fellowship and cooperation in God’s work.

questions.question: What does 1 Kings 5 teach about the importance of honesty and integrity in agreements?
options: Keeping fair agreements strengthens trust and peace
Breaking promises is acceptable if convenient
Agreements should be vague to avoid responsibility
questions.correctAnswer: Keeping fair agreements strengthens trust and peace
questions.explanation: Solomon and Hiram made a league and traded wood for food yearly (verses 8-11), maintaining peace through honest and fair dealings.

questions.question: How does Solomon’s respect for his father David exemplify biblical obedience and faithfulness?
options: By fulfilling the promise to build the temple
questions.correctAnswer: By fulfilling the promise to build the temple
questions.explanation: Solomon states in 1 Kings 5:5 that he will build the house as the LORD told David, showing obedience and faithfulness to God’s covenant.

questions.question: A believer feels overwhelmed by the size of a task. Based on 1 Kings 5, what encouragement about perseverance and teamwork can you offer?
options: Large tasks can be accomplished by many working together over time
Only small tasks are worth doing
One should quit if a task seems too big
Depend solely on your own strength
questions.correctAnswer: Large tasks can be accomplished by many working together over time
questions.explanation: Solomon’s workforce was divided into rotations (1 Kings 5:14) and had thousands of laborers and supervisors (verses 15-16), showing perseverance through teamwork.

questions.question: True or False: According to 1 Kings 5, God gave Solomon wisdom to lead wisely and maintain peace.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 5:12 confirms that the LORD gave Solomon wisdom as promised and there was peace between him and Hiram, illustrating God’s blessing on wise leadership.

questions.question: True or False: Solomon relied only on his own people to gather materials for the temple without any foreign assistance.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 5:6-10 shows Solomon requesting cedar and fir timber from Hiram’s Sidonian servants, indicating reliance on foreign help for materials.

questions.question: What does Solomon’s arrangement with Hiram teach us about generosity and stewardship in relationships?
options: Generosity involves fair exchange and mutual benefit
Generosity means giving without any expectations
questions.correctAnswer: Generosity involves fair exchange and mutual benefit
questions.explanation: Solomon gave Hiram wheat and oil annually in exchange for timber (1 Kings 5:10-11), exemplifying generous stewardship and honoring agreements.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with contentment in their current circumstances. How does Solomon’s statement in 1 Kings 5:4 encourage contentment and trust in God’s timing?
options: God provides rest and removes adversaries in His perfect timing
God only blesses when there is no difficulty
We must create our own peace
questions.correctAnswer: God provides rest and removes adversaries in His perfect timing
questions.explanation: Solomon notes the LORD gave him rest on every side with no adversaries (1 Kings 5:4), illustrating trust in God’s sovereign timing for peace and contentment.

questions.question: How does 1 Kings 5 teach us about prayer and seeking God’s guidance before undertaking important work?
options: Solomon sought God’s promise through his father’s words before building
God’s guidance is unnecessary for important tasks
questions.correctAnswer: Solomon sought God’s promise through his father’s words before building
questions.explanation: Solomon references God's promise to David about building the house (1 Kings 5:5), showing reliance on divine guidance before starting.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Solomon sent a levy of __________ men to Lebanon to work on the building project, rotating monthly.
questions.correctAnswer: thirty thousand
questions.explanation: According to 1 Kings 5:13-14, Solomon raised a levy of thirty thousand men, sending ten thousand each month on rotation to work in Lebanon.

questions.question: How does the collaboration between Solomon’s and Hiram’s builders in 1 Kings 5 demonstrate the value of unity in the church or community work?
options: Unified work combines different skills for a common goal
Each group should work separately to avoid conflict
Unity is not necessary for success
questions.correctAnswer: Unified work combines different skills for a common goal
questions.explanation: Verse 18 shows Solomon’s and Hiram’s builders working together hewing stones and timber, illustrating how unity enhances effective service.

questions.question: What does 1 Kings 5 teach about leadership responsibility in overseeing large tasks?
options: Leaders must appoint capable officers to manage workers
Leaders should micromanage every task personally
Leadership means doing all work alone
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders must appoint capable officers to manage workers
questions.explanation: Verse 16 mentions Solomon’s officers who ruled over the workers, demonstrating responsible delegation in leadership.

hard.title: 1 Kings Chapter 5 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 1 Kings Chapter 5.

questions.question: What motivated King Hiram of Tyre to send servants to Solomon according to 1 Kings 5:1?
options: He heard Solomon was anointed king in place of David
He wanted to declare war on Israel
He sought a trade agreement for gold
He wished to form an alliance with neighboring kingdoms
questions.correctAnswer: He heard Solomon was anointed king in place of David
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 5:1 states that Hiram sent his servants to Solomon because he heard that Solomon had been anointed king in the room of his father David.

questions.question: In 1 Kings 5:3-5, Solomon refers to a promise made to David regarding the building of the temple. What is the nature of this promise?
options: David’s son would build a house for the name of the LORD
David himself would build the temple after his wars
The temple would be built by foreign kings
The temple was to be made of gold and precious stones
questions.correctAnswer: David’s son would build a house for the name of the LORD
questions.explanation: Solomon explains that David could not build the temple because of wars, but God promised David that his son would build the house for the LORD’s name (1 Kings 5:3-5).

questions.question: What is the significance of Solomon's phrase 'rest on every side' in 1 Kings 5:4 within the broader biblical theme of peace and divine favor?
options: It signifies God's blessing through peace, enabling temple construction
It indicates a temporary truce with neighboring kingdoms
It refers to a cessation of natural disasters
It is a metaphor for economic prosperity only
questions.correctAnswer: It signifies God's blessing through peace, enabling temple construction
questions.explanation: Solomon credits the LORD for granting him rest on every side, meaning peace from enemies which allowed him to fulfill God's plan to build the temple (1 Kings 5:4). This echoes the biblical motif of peace as a sign of divine favor.

questions.question: Which tree species did Solomon request from Hiram for building the temple, as noted in 1 Kings 5:6?
questions.correctAnswer: Cedar trees
questions.explanation: Solomon specifically asked Hiram to command his men to hew cedar trees from Lebanon because of their superior quality and the Sidonians’ skill in timber work (1 Kings 5:6).

questions.question: According to 1 Kings 5:6, why did Solomon mention the Sidonians’ skill in timber work?
options: Because no one among the Israelites could match their expertise
To suggest they should be trained in Israel
To indicate a potential threat from Tyre’s workers
questions.correctAnswer: Because no one among the Israelites could match their expertise
questions.explanation: Solomon acknowledged that the Sidonians possessed unique skill in hewing timber, which Israel lacked, thus justifying his request for Hiram’s assistance (1 Kings 5:6).

questions.question: What was Hiram’s reaction upon hearing Solomon’s message, and what does it reveal about his view of Solomon according to 1 Kings 5:7?
options: He rejoiced and blessed the LORD for giving David a wise son
He was suspicious and delayed his response
He sent a hostile reply demanding tribute
questions.correctAnswer: He rejoiced and blessed the LORD for giving David a wise son
questions.explanation: Hiram rejoiced greatly and blessed the LORD, recognizing Solomon’s wisdom and his rightful place as king (1 Kings 5:7).

questions.question: How did Hiram propose to transport the timber from Lebanon to Solomon’s designated location according to 1 Kings 5:8-9?
options: By bringing it down to the sea and sending it via sea floats
By carrying it over land with camels
By building a canal between Lebanon and Israel
questions.correctAnswer: By bringing it down to the sea and sending it via sea floats
questions.explanation: Hiram described his plan to bring timber down from Lebanon to the sea and then float it by sea to the place Solomon would appoint (1 Kings 5:8-9).

questions.question: What was the nature of the exchange between Solomon and Hiram as detailed in 1 Kings 5:10-11?
options: Timber in exchange for wheat and oil supplied yearly
questions.correctAnswer: Timber in exchange for wheat and oil supplied yearly
questions.explanation: Hiram gave Solomon timber according to his desire, and Solomon in turn gave Hiram twenty thousand measures of wheat and twenty measures of pure oil annually (1 Kings 5:10-11).

questions.question: What divine gift did the LORD grant Solomon as mentioned in 1 Kings 5:12, and how did it impact his relationship with Hiram?
options: Wisdom, resulting in peace and a league between them
questions.correctAnswer: Wisdom, resulting in peace and a league between them
questions.explanation: The LORD gave Solomon wisdom as promised, leading to peace between him and Hiram and the establishment of a league (1 Kings 5:12).

questions.question: How many men did Solomon levy from all Israel for the temple construction project as described in 1 Kings 5:13?
questions.correctAnswer: Thirty thousand
questions.explanation: Solomon raised a levy of thirty thousand men from all Israel for the work (1 Kings 5:13).

questions.question: What was the rotation schedule for the thirty thousand men working in Lebanon, according to 1 Kings 5:14?
options: Ten thousand worked each month, one month in Lebanon and two months at home
Five thousand worked each month, two months in Lebanon and one month at home
They only worked during harvest season
questions.correctAnswer: Ten thousand worked each month, one month in Lebanon and two months at home
questions.explanation: Solomon sent ten thousand men each month, who worked one month in Lebanon and then stayed two months at home (1 Kings 5:14).

questions.question: According to 1 Kings 5:15-16, besides the thirty thousand levy, what other groups of workers were involved in the temple construction?
options: Seventy thousand burden bearers, eighty thousand hewers, and 3,300 overseers
questions.correctAnswer: Seventy thousand burden bearers, eighty thousand hewers, and 3,300 overseers
questions.explanation: The text details seventy thousand burden bearers, eighty thousand hewers in the mountains, and 3,300 chief officers overseeing the work (1 Kings 5:15-16).

questions.question: What types of stones did Solomon command to be brought for the temple foundation as stated in 1 Kings 5:17?
options: Great stones, costly stones, and hewed stones
questions.correctAnswer: Great stones, costly stones, and hewed stones
questions.explanation: Solomon commanded the gathering of great, costly, and hewed stones to lay the temple foundation (1 Kings 5:17).

questions.question: True or False: According to 1 Kings 5:18, the timber and stones for the temple were prepared exclusively by Israelite builders.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Solomon’s builders and Hiram’s builders together, along with stonesquarers, prepared the timber and stones (1 Kings 5:18), indicating a collaborative effort.

questions.question: How does the alliance between Solomon and Hiram in 1 Kings 5 reflect the political and economic realities of the ancient Near East?
options: It exemplifies trade and mutual support between neighboring kingdoms
It reflects a vassal-lord relationship with Solomon as vassal
It was primarily a religious alliance against Egypt
It was a secret pact to conquer Phoenicia
questions.correctAnswer: It exemplifies trade and mutual support between neighboring kingdoms
questions.explanation: The mutual exchange of resources and manpower shows typical diplomatic and economic cooperation between neighboring states in the ancient Near East (1 Kings 5:8-12).

theological.title: 1 Kings Chapter 5 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 1 Kings Chapter 5 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What reason did Solomon give to Hiram for why David could not build the house for the LORD?
options: Because of the wars around him
Because he was not anointed king
questions.correctAnswer: Because of the wars around him
questions.explanation: Solomon explains in 1 Kings 5:3 that David could not build the house due to the wars surrounding him. This reflects God's providence and timing in the fulfillment of His promises, consistent with other scriptures such as 2 Samuel 7:1-2 and Psalm 127:1.

questions.question: According to Solomon, what condition allowed him now to build the house for the LORD?
options: There was peace and rest on every side
questions.correctAnswer: There was peace and rest on every side
questions.explanation: In 1 Kings 5:4, Solomon states that the LORD has given him rest on every side, meaning there was no enemy or trouble, allowing him to build the temple. This demonstrates the divine timing of God's plans, aligning with passages like Nehemiah 2:8 and Isaiah 32:17.

questions.question: What was the LORD's promise to David regarding the building of the house?
options: David himself would build the house
David's son would build the house
The house would never be built
questions.correctAnswer: David's son would build the house
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 5:5 recounts God's promise that David's son, Solomon, whom He would set on David's throne, would build a house for His name. This messianic promise aligns with 2 Samuel 7:12-13 and is fulfilled in the typology of Christ as the true builder of God's spiritual temple in the New Testament (Ephesians 2:20-22).

questions.question: Why did Solomon specifically request cedar trees from Lebanon?
options: Because cedar was abundant in Israel
Because the Sidonians were skilled in timber hewing
Because he wanted to build a palace
questions.correctAnswer: Because the Sidonians were skilled in timber hewing
questions.explanation: Solomon requests cedar from Lebanon and mentions that no one among them can skillfully hew timber like the Sidonians (1 Kings 5:6). This highlights God's providential use of skilled peoples for His purposes, consistent with Exodus 31:3-5 and Psalm 127:1.

questions.question: How did Hiram respond to Solomon's request for timber?
options: He rejoiced and agreed to provide the timber
questions.correctAnswer: He rejoiced and agreed to provide the timber
questions.explanation: Hiram rejoiced greatly upon hearing Solomon's words and agreed to supply the timber (1 Kings 5:7-8). This mutual cooperation shows God's providential orchestration of alliances, similar to David's relationship with Hiram in 2 Samuel 5:11 and God's use of Gentiles in Acts 10.

questions.question: What was the method Hiram proposed to deliver the timber to Solomon?
questions.correctAnswer: By floats on the sea
questions.explanation: Hiram proposed to bring the timber down from Lebanon to the sea and convey it by sea in floats to the appointed place (1 Kings 5:9). This logistical detail reflects God's providential care in the building of His temple, paralleling the transportation of materials for the tabernacle in Exodus 25 and Nehemiah 3.

questions.question: What did Solomon give to Hiram in exchange for the timber?
questions.correctAnswer: Wheat and pure oil
questions.explanation: Solomon gave Hiram twenty thousand measures of wheat and twenty measures of pure oil annually (1 Kings 5:11). This exchange shows a peaceful covenant and mutual provision, reflecting biblical principles of justice and trade in Leviticus 19:13 and Proverbs 11:1.

questions.question: What blessing did Hiram attribute to the LORD upon hearing about Solomon?
options: Blessed be the LORD for His mercy
Blessed be the LORD for giving David a wise son
Blessed be the LORD for riches
Blessed be the LORD for His strength
questions.correctAnswer: Blessed be the LORD for giving David a wise son
questions.explanation: Hiram praised the LORD for giving David a wise son over the great people (1 Kings 5:7). This acknowledgment of divine wisdom aligns with the biblical theme of wisdom as a gift from God (James 1:5, Proverbs 2:6).

questions.question: What wisdom-related gift did the LORD give Solomon according to the chapter?
options: Peace and a league with Hiram
questions.correctAnswer: Wisdom as He promised
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 5:12 states that the LORD gave Solomon wisdom as He had promised him, along with peace and a covenant with Hiram. This confirms the fulfillment of God's promise and the importance of divine wisdom for leadership, as also seen in 1 Kings 3:12 and James 3:17.

questions.question: What was the size of the levy Solomon raised for the building project?
questions.correctAnswer: Thirty thousand men
questions.explanation: Solomon raised a levy of thirty thousand men from all Israel for the work (1 Kings 5:13). This large workforce reflects the communal effort in fulfilling God's plan, similar to the labor for the tabernacle in Exodus 36:1-2 and the rebuilding of Jerusalem in Nehemiah 4:6.

questions.question: How was the rotation of the thirty thousand men organized during the work in Lebanon?
options: Ten thousand a month in rotation
questions.correctAnswer: Ten thousand a month in rotation
questions.explanation: Solomon sent them in courses of ten thousand a month: one month in Lebanon and two months at home (1 Kings 5:14). This work schedule highlights orderly management and stewardship, reflecting biblical principles of rest and labor such as Exodus 20:9-10 and Ecclesiastes 3:1.

questions.question: Besides the workers, how many carried burdens and hewed the mountains for the building?
options: Seventy thousand burden bearers and eighty thousand hewers
questions.correctAnswer: Seventy thousand burden bearers and eighty thousand hewers
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 5:15 states Solomon had seventy thousand burden bearers and eighty thousand hewers in the mountains. This highlights the extensive preparation and labor for the temple, paralleling the labor force in 2 Chronicles 2:17 and Exodus 1:14.

questions.question: Who was over the levy of thirty thousand men working on the building?
questions.correctAnswer: Adoniram
questions.explanation: Adoniram was appointed over the levy as commander (1 Kings 5:14). This shows the organized leadership structure in God's work, consistent with similar appointments in Numbers 1:5-16 and 1 Chronicles 27:31.

questions.question: What types of stones were brought to lay the foundation of the house?
options: Great stones, costly stones, and hewed stones
questions.correctAnswer: Great stones, costly stones, and hewed stones
questions.explanation: Solomon commanded bringing great, costly, and hewed stones for the foundation (1 Kings 5:17). This indicates the temple's sacredness and God's glory, paralleling the use of precious materials in Exodus 25:10-22 and 1 Peter 2:5.

questions.question: Who worked together to prepare the timber and stones for the temple?
options: Solomon's builders, Hiram's builders, and stonesquarers
questions.correctAnswer: Solomon's builders, Hiram's builders, and stonesquarers
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 5:18 says Solomon's and Hiram's builders and stonesquarers worked together to prepare materials. This cooperation reflects God's providential orchestration of diverse peoples for His purposes, similar to Nehemiah 3 and Ezra 3.

questions.question: What theological theme is emphasized by the peaceful alliance between Solomon and Hiram?
questions.correctAnswer: Divine wisdom and covenantal peace
questions.explanation: The peace and league between Hiram and Solomon (1 Kings 5:12) highlight God's wisdom in establishing covenantal relationships for His redemptive purposes. This theme is consistent with Isaiah 54:10, Romans 12:18, and Ephesians 2:14.

questions.question: What does the chapter reveal about the attribute of God in relation to Solomon's wisdom and peace?
options: God is distant from human affairs
God grants wisdom and peace to His people
questions.correctAnswer: God grants wisdom and peace to His people
questions.explanation: The LORD gave Solomon wisdom and peace (1 Kings 5:12), demonstrating God's gracious provision of spiritual gifts necessary for righteous leadership. This reflects James 1:5, Proverbs 2:6, and John 14:27 about God's gifts of wisdom and peace.
